model_completion: Esophagitis is the inflammation of the lining of the esophagus and is typically caused by acid reflux. GERD is the medical term for acid reflux. In GERD, stomach acids flow up into the esophagus, causing irritation and inflammation. Esophagitis can lead to scarring of the esophagus and increase the risk for cancer. Esophagitis can be diagnosed with an endoscopy, during which a long tube is passed down the throat to examine the lining of the esophagus. Esophagitis is typically treated with medications that reduce stomach acid, although surgery is an option in some cases.

The symptoms of esophagitis depend on the underlying cause. GERD is the most common cause, and is associated with heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain, hoarseness, trouble swallowing, sore throat, bad breath, bloating, belching, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, dental erosion, cough, wheezing, asthma, sinus infections, ear infections, nosebleeds, postnasal drip, hoarse voice, laryngitis, hiccups, bloody stools, rectal itching, anal fissures, rectal bleeding, rectal prolapse, hematochezia, melena, iron deficiency anemia, peptic ulcer, hiatal hernia, malnutrition, fatigue, fibromyalgia, migraines, neuropathy, thyroid

Esophagitis can be diagnosed with a physical exam, endoscopy and biopsy. A doctor will ask the patient questions about his or her medical history, symptoms, risk factors, family medical history, medications being taken and exposures to irritants. Esophagitis is diagnosed with endoscopy, a test that allows doctors to look at the lining of the esophagus with a lighted tube. Doctors can take tissue samples with the endoscope to check for H. pylori bacteria. Sometimes doctors take an upper GI series to evaluate the esophagus. This test involves drinking barium solution, which coats the esophagus so doctors can get X-ray images of the esophagus. In some cases, the doctor may do a biopsy, taking a tissue sample and checking it under a microscope. This test helps doctors

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus and is commonly treated with acid-reducing medications. Depending on the severity, your physician may prescribe antacids, H2 blockers, proton pump inhibitors, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate, corticosteroids, sucralfate, sucrose octaacetate

Esophagitis can be prevented by not smoking, eating smaller meals, chewing slowly, drinking fluids between meals, raising the head of the bed, losing weight, quitting alcohol, using nonprescription acid reducers and following your physician's orders.

Dysentery is an intestinal infection that causes severe diarrhea. It is typically caused by a bacterium called shigella, although a parasitic infection caused by giardia is another potential cause. Shigellosis is highly contagious and is spread when an individual comes in contact with stool from an infected person. Other risk factors for dysentery include drinking unclean water, eating raw or undercooked meat, eating unwashed fruits and vegetables, and not washing one's hands after going to the bathroom. The most common symptom of dysentery is watery diarrhea, often containing blood and mucus. The diarrhea is often severe, with up to 20 bowel movements a day. In some cases, the patient may experience nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, chills

Dysentery is diagnosed based on a person's signs and symptoms, stool test results, and physical exam. Sometimes, a doctor will take a sample of the patient's stool to look for parasites that cause dysentery. It's important for patients to see a health care professional right away if they think they have dysentery so that the condition doesn't worsen.

Dysentery is typically treated with antibiotics. Sometimes, patients are given fluids through an intravenous line to replenish fluids that were lost. Patients are encouraged to drink plenty of fluids to help flush out any bacteria that are causing the diarrhea. Depending on the patient's condition, they may be admitted to the hospital so that their fluids can be closely monitored. In severe cases, patients may need to be placed on intravenous fluids to rehydrate the body. In very severe cases, patients may need a blood transfusion.

Dysentery is typically spread when an individual comes in contact with fecal matter. The bacteria that cause dysentery live in the intestines of humans and animals. It is typically spread when an individual drinks water that has been contaminated with feces, such as swallowing water from a lake, stream, pond, well, swimming pool, hot tub, spa, bath, sink, toilet, sewage, raw shellfish, raw milk, raw meat, unwashed fruits or vegetables, or unwashed hands. Dysentery can also spread when an individual comes in contact with an object, surface, food, clothing, bedding, towel, diaper, utensil, dish, toilet seat, door knob, bathtub, shower, sinks, floors, furniture, pet, animal, human, clothing, bedding,

Some risk factors for dysentery include drinking unpurified water, not washing hands after going to the bathroom, eating raw fruits and vegetables, not washing meat thoroughly, eating undercooked meat, being around livestock, not washing your hands after changing a baby's diaper, not washing your hands after using the toilet, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with dysentery, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with diarrhea, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with vomiting, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with fever, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with jaundice, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with chickenpox, not washing your hands after taking care of a person with impetigo, not washing your hands

Dysentery is typically contracted when an individual comes in contact with fecal matter. It is important to wash your hands frequently, especially before eating, to reduce the chances of contracting dysentery. You should also drink only boiled, purified, or bottled water. When traveling, it is important to eat only cooked food that has been washed thoroughly. This will reduce the chances of contracting dysentery. If you do contract dysentery, you should see your health care provider right away to receive antibiotic treatment.

The treatment for dementia is highly individualized and depends on the patient's diagnosis. It's important for patients to see a neurologist to make a proper diagnosis, since dementia has many possible causes. After making a proper diagnosis, patients are often started on cholinesterase inhibitors to improve memory. Some patients are started on memantine, a drug that reduces the activity of glutamate receptors. This reduces some of the excitotoxicity that occurs with Alzheimer's disease. In the later stages, patients are started on antidepressants to reduce agitation. Patients are often started on vitamins B12, folate, thiamine, and coenzyme Q10 to reduce fatigue.

It's important for individuals living with dementia to maintain a routine to help reduce stress. In addition, it's helpful for caregivers to learn the warning signs that indicate the patient is having a bad day. They should be prepared to recognize the early warning signs so that they can take appropriate actions to reduce the patient's discomfort. This will help everyone feel calmer, which may decrease agitation. It's important that everyone involved understand the importance of reducing stress for the patient. This can be accomplished through activities that stimulate the senses, such as listening to music, walking outside, watching a movie, reading, going out to eat, doing crafts, watching sports, doing puzzles, doing word searches, doing art projects, listening to stories, listening to comedy shows, looking at photographs, listening to books on tape, listening to classical music, walking around the house, sitting in a hot tub, walking in the park, walking on

Tonsillitis is the inflammation of the tonsils, and the main symptom is sore throat. The tonsils are lymph tissues at the back of the throat that help the body fight off infections. Tonsillitis is commonly caused by a virus, but bacteria, allergens, environmental irritants, smoking, alcohol use, poor hygiene, stress, fatigue, dental problems, sinus infections, post nasal drip, acid reflux, GERD, LPR, heartburn, hiatal hernias, acid indigestion, ulcers, cancer, diabetes, thyroid disease, liver disease, lung disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, COPD, pneumonia, mononucleosis, Epstein Barr, mono, strep throat, scarlet fever

A physician will ask the patient about his or her medical history, perform a physical exam and run any necessary lab tests to help make a diagnosis. Depending on the patient's symptoms, the physician may order a chest x-ray to see if the patient has pneumonia, a sputum culture to identify an infection, a throat swab to detect strep throat, a complete blood count to evaluate the patient's white blood cell count, which helps indicate if the patient has an infection, or a rapid strep test. The physician will also listen to the patient's lungs to hear wheezing, crackling, rales, decreased breath sounds, rhonchi, hyperresonance, reduced air entry, prolonged expiratory phase, prolonged inspiratory phase, prolonged expiratory phase, prolonged inspiratory phase, reduced respiratory rate, retractions, stridor, dys

Tonsillitis is typically treated with antibiotics to kill any infections that are causing the tonsillitis and reduce swelling. Pain relievers are used to reduce discomfort, and decongestants can be prescribed to reduce swelling. Depending on the patient's medical history, the physician may choose to remove the tonsils. Tonsillectomies are generally safe, with the risks and benefits being weighed on an individual basis. Risks associated with tonsillectomies include infection, bleeding, nausea, vomiting, sore throat, ear infections, breathing difficulties, hoarseness, swallowing problems, speech problems, sinus infections, nose bleeds, blood clots, excessive bleeding, blood poisoning, blood cell changes, blood vessel changes, blood clot in the throat, neck stiffness, skin rash, hair loss

Tonsillitis is typically a self-limiting infection, and the body fights off the bacteria on its own. In some cases, the tonsils can swell so much that they block the airway, causing difficulty breathing. The tonsils can also become infected, leading to abscess formation. An abscess is a collection of pus that forms at the site of infection. When the tonsils become infected, the abscess is known as quinsy. It is important to see your primary care physician if you think you have tonsillitis so that you can be diagnosed and treated promptly.

Tonsillitis is typically a viral infection, so the best prevention is washing your hands regularly. Avoiding close contact with individuals who have the infection and not sharing drinks, utensils, towels, toys, or kissing is also important. Getting vaccinated against the flu can help reduce the chances of contracting tonsillitis, since many cases are caused by the flu. Antibiotics are not effective in treating tonsillitis because the infection is caused by a virus.

The primary home remedies that can help treat tonsillitis are rest, fluids, ice packs to the throat, gargling salt water, sucking on lozenges, taking acetaminophen for fever, and using decongestant sprays. It's important that individuals see their physician to diagnose tonsillitis and make sure the condition isn't strep throat, as antibiotics are required to treat strep infections.

Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin that causes the skin to become red, swollen, hot, tender and painful. In some cases, the lymph nodes near the infected area can become enlarged. It is important to see your primary care physician right away if you think you have cellulitis because the condition can worsen quickly and lead to sepsis if not treated immediately. The symptoms of cellulitis include the following: Fever Rash, which is warm, red, tender, firm, swollen, painful, and/or shiny Blistering, oozing, crusting, cracking, peeling, scaling, or flaking Drainage, pus, or discharge Lymph node tenderness, enlargement, or warmth Weakness, fatigue, confusion, or dizziness Nausea, vomiting, diarrhe

Cellulitis is diagnosed based on a physical exam and medical history. Your physician will ask about your medical history to see if you have had cellulitis before and to identify risk factors, such as cuts, burns, animal bites, surgery, obesity, diabetes, intravenous drug use, poor circulation, cancer, liver disease, heart disease, HIV, malnutrition, necrotizing fasciitis and lymphedema. You will be asked to describe the symptoms you've experienced, when the symptoms started, where the symptoms are located, if the symptoms have changed, if the symptoms are constant, and if the symptoms have gotten better, worse or stayed the same. A physical exam will be done to look for swelling, tenderness, redness, warmth, drainage, rash, blistering, peeling, cracking

Cellulitis is typically treated with oral antibiotics. Sometimes, intravenous antibiotics are required, depending on the severity of the cellulitis and the patient's medical condition. Wounds are typically drained to reduce swelling. Pain control is important, as cellulitis is very painful. Depending on the patient, surgery may be required to drain the abscess, but this is typically not required.

Cellulitis is typically caused by bacteria entering the body through a break in the skin. Lifestyle changes are critical in helping to prevent cellulitis. Washing the infected area with mild soap and warm water, keeping the infected area dry, wearing loose-fitting clothing, using powders to keep the infected area dry, keeping the infected area elevated, applying cold packs, using nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications and not smoking can all help reduce the chances of cellulitis developing. If cellulitis develops, the patient should see his or her primary health care provider immediately to receive antibiotic treatment.

Vasculitis is inflammation of the blood vessels, and the symptoms that a patient experiences can vary based on which blood vessel is involved. When blood vessels in the skin are affected, the patient may experience rash, sores, ulcers, bruising, purpura, hair loss, itching, burning, numbness, tingling, weakness, cold hands and feet, Raynaud's phenomenon, gangrene, pain, swelling, redness, paleness, discolored fingers, blistering, scarring, thickening, hardening, bulging, nodules, ulcerations, cysts, tumors, necrosis, skin discoloration, color changes, hair loss, thinning, dandruff, thinning, shedding, itching, scaling, thickening, thinning, broken blood vessels, cracked, peeling, splitting, shedding, shedding

To make a diagnosis, your physician will perform a physical exam to evaluate the function of your organs. In some cases, imaging tests are ordered to examine the structure of the organs. A biopsy is the gold standard to make a diagnosis. A biopsy involves the removal of a tissue sample and evaluation under a microscope. Depending on the organ system involved, your physician may order additional testing to identify the specific disease causing vasculitis.

The treatment for vasculitis depends on the underlying condition causing the disease and the specific symptoms a patient experiences. Patients are often prescribed corticosteroid medications to reduce the body's immune response. Sometimes, patients are given immunosuppressant medications to reduce the activity of the immune system. Depending on the patient's symptoms, surgery may be required to repair blood vessel damage. In severe cases, dialysis may be required.

Vasculitis is inflammation of the blood vessel walls. Inflammation occurs when the body's white blood cells release substances that injure the blood vessel walls. Causes of vasculitis include infections, allergies, environmental irritants, autoimmune disorders, cancer, genetic disorders, certain medications, and reactions to radiation. Some forms of vasculitis, such as Kawasaki disease, are primarily seen in children. The disease is characterized by high fever, rash, mouth sores, red eyes, swollen lymph nodes, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, peeling of the palms and soles, and changes in the fingers. The diagnosis is confirmed with blood tests that show an elevated white blood cell count. The diagnosis is made by ruling out other diseases that can cause vasculitis. The goal of treatment

Inflammation of the blood vessels is known as vasculitis. When the walls of the blood vessels become inflamed, this can lead to narrowing, scarring, weakening, blockage, leakage, clot formation, bleeding, aneurysm and ulceration. Depending on the underlying cause, vasculitis can affect any part of the body. When vasculitis occurs in the skin, the rash is known as cutaneous vasculitis. Some potential complications of vasculitis include poor healing, decreased blood supply, damage to nerves, skin ulceration, blood clots, eye problems, respiratory problems, heart problems, stroke, seizures, coma, organ failure, death and cancer.

Making some lifestyle changes can help reduce the symptoms of vasculitis and reduce the chances of a relapse. There are a wide variety of symptoms associated with liver cancer, and each patient's experience is different. Some patients do not experience any symptoms at all and the disease is diagnosed on a routine physical exam. In other patients, the disease is diagnosed only after the patient seeks medical care because of abdominal discomfort. This discomfort can be related to enlargement of the liver, jaundice, itching, weight loss, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, swollen abdomen, weakness, fever, dark urine, pale stool, light-colored stool, clay-colored stool, bloody stool, itchy skin, yellow eyes, itchy skin, swollen face, swollen legs, swollen feet, swollen hands, swollen ankles, swollen belly, swollen breasts,

In the early stages, liver cancer is not always diagnosed, since the signs and symptoms can be similar to those of less serious conditions. A liver biopsy is the best method of diagnosing liver cancer. A needle is used to remove a tissue sample from the liver, and this tissue is examined under a microscope. A liver biopsy is the only way to diagnose primary liver cancer. It is important to diagnose liver cancer as soon as possible, since the earlier the diagnosis, the greater the chances for successful treatment.

The main treatment for liver cancer is surgery to remove the tumor. A liver transplant is another treatment option, but the liver must be functioning properly to undergo the transplant. In the event the liver is too diseased to undergo transplant, the cancer is treated with chemotherapy. A liver biopsy is the primary method of staging liver cancer, and this test involves using a needle to remove a small piece of liver tissue for examination. This allows doctors to determine the stage of the cancer and develop a treatment plan.

The liver plays an important role in many bodily processes, and cancer that starts in the liver can have significant effects on a patient's overall health. It is the third-leading cause of cancer-related death in the U.S., and approximately 32,000 new cases are diagnosed each year. In addition to causing symptoms related to the liver, liver cancer can lead to jaundice, enlarged spleen, itchy skin, itchy palms, weight loss, weakness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, swollen abdomen, dark urine, pale stool, light-colored stool, clay-colored stool, bloody stool, fever, chills, night sweats, itching, rash, hives, joint pain, muscle aches, headache, dizziness, confusion, slurred speech,

Maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking, limiting alcohol intake, eating a well-balanced diet, exercising regularly, getting vaccinated for hepatitis B, getting tested regularly for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, syphilis, human papillomavirus, and receiving regular medical care are some lifestyle changes that can help prevent liver cancer. In addition, individuals with cirrhosis should not drink alcohol. People at high risk for liver cancer should talk to their doctor about getting vaccinated against hepatitis B.

Bronchitis is inflammation of the large airways of the lungs, causing excess mucus to accumulate. It is typically caused by infection, though smoking, chemical fumes, dust, secondhand smoke, allergens, cold air, pollutants, irritants, dry air, viruses, bacteria, environmental toxins, chemical fumes, dust, secondhand smoke and cigarette smoking can all contribute to its development. Bronchitis causes cough, phlegm, wheezing, shortness of breath, fatigue, chest tightness, fever, runny nose, sore throat, headache, back pain, muscle aches, shaking, sweating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss, anxiety, insomnia, restlessness, rapid heartbeat, palpitations, irregular heartbeat, lightheaded

Bronchitis is diagnosed based on the patient's medical history, a physical exam and chest x-ray. In many cases, doctors will perform a sputum culture to identify the bacteria causing the infection. Bronchitis is typically treated with rest, fluids, humid air, cough drops, expectorants, lozenges, steam inhalation, hot showers, warm drinks, hot packs, acetaminophen, ibuprofen, codeine, narcotics, corticosteroids, antibiotics, nebulizers, chest physiotherapy, vapocoolants, mucus thinners, aromatherapy, chiropractic manipulation, osteopathy, aromatherapy, aroma inhalers, essential oils, vitamins, antioxidants, nutritional supplements, antispasmodics, breathing techniques, biofeedback, stress reduction, hypnotherapy, guided imagery, relaxation, herbs, teas, flower essences, aromatherapy, meditation, home

Bronchitis occurs when the tubes that carry air to the lungs become irritated and swollen, causing excess mucus to be produced. Cigarette smoking is the main cause of chronic bronchitis, although people with asthma, recurring respiratory infections, allergies, heart disease, COPD and emphysema are at higher risk for developing chronic bronchitis. Infections that cause acute bronchitis include colds, flu, measles, pertussis, whooping cough, chicken pox, measles, tuberculosis, whooping cough, influenza, croup, RSV, HPV, adenoviruses, mycoplasma pneumonia, Legionella, pneumocystis, bacteria, fungi, parasites, environmental irritants, chemical fumes, dust,

Cigarette smoking is the biggest risk factor for bronchitis. Exposure to secondhand smoke and pollutants also increases a person's risk. Infections, allergies, asthma, environmental irritants, obesity, excessive alcohol consumption, poor nutrition, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and acid reflux also increase a person's risk for bronchitis.

Lifestyle changes that can help reduce the frequency and severity of bronchitis symptoms include quitting smoking, staying well-hydrated, eating a healthy diet, getting plenty of rest, using a humidifier, exercising regularly, reducing exposure to secondhand smoke, washing your hands frequently, getting vaccinated against flu, pneumonia, tetanus, pertussis, measles, mumps, rubella, shingles, hepatitis B, chickenpox, human papillomavirus, meningococcal, rotavirus, polio, diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, Haemophilus influenzae type b, varicella, herpes zoster, hepatitis A, hepatitis B, hepatitis A, pneumococcal, HPV, MMR, IPV, PCV

Goitres are swellings that develop in the neck because the thyroid gland enlarges. Thyroid enlargement occurs when the thyroid produces too much hormone. A goitre is the most common sign of an overactive thyroid. Some goitres are painless, and the patient is not aware that the thyroid is enlarged. In other patients, the goitre is painful and makes it hard for the patient to breathe. Sometimes the patient experiences shortness of breath, wheezing, chest tightness, hoarseness, trouble swallowing, dry mouth, weight loss, fatigue, palpitations, heat intolerance, anxiety, irritability, nervousness, tremors, sweating, constipation, diarrhea, menstrual irregularities, thinning hair, brittle nails, thin skin, thin eyebrows, thin

A goitre is diagnosed based on the patient's medical history, a physical exam and imaging tests, such as ultrasound. During a physical exam, the physician will feel the thyroid to check for swelling. An ultrasound uses sound waves to create an image of the thyroid. Sometimes, the physician will order blood tests to look for an underactive thyroid. These blood tests measure the amount of thyroid hormone in the blood. If the physician thinks the patient has hyperthyroidism, he or she may order a radioactive iodine uptake test. During this test, the patient swallows a dose of a radioactive isotope of iodine. The physician will then perform another ultrasound to check the patient's thyroid to see where the isotope collects. The patient is not exposed to any harmful amounts of radiation during the test.

A goitre is an enlargement of the thyroid gland. Depending on the underlying cause, the goitre can be treated medically, surgically or not at all. Medical management involves using thyroid hormone replacement medications to reduce the swelling of the goitre. These medications help reduce the pressure that is put on the windpipe when the goitre gets too big. Sometimes surgery is required to remove the goitre. If the goitre is the result of an underactive thyroid, the patient's doctor may suggest the patient take thyroid hormone medication. This helps shrink the goitre so it's no longer visible. Surgery is another option to treat goitres that are the result of overactive thyroid. In some cases, surgery is the only treatment necessary. In other cases, surgery is done first to shrink the goitre, and the patient takes

A goitre is the enlargement of the thyroid gland, and the main cause is an underactive thyroid. An overactive thyroid can also lead to goitres, and sometimes patients will experience goitres that are the result of a combination of an overactive and underactive thyroid. Sometimes patients will develop goitres as the result of certain medications they take, which is why patients are advised to tell their physicians about all the medications they take. Patients with an enlarged thyroid should see their physicians regularly so that the physician can monitor the patient for changes in the goitre that could indicate the development of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism.

A goitre is the enlargement of the thyroid gland, and risk factors for developing one include being female, taking estrogen supplements, a family history of goiters, smoking, pregnancy, having certain autoimmune disorders, taking iodine supplements, taking lithium, taking amiodarone, eating too much soy, taking steroid medications, taking a drug that increases the activity of the thyroid and taking excess vitamin A.

A goitre is typically diagnosed based on physical exam and imaging studies, such as ultrasound. Depending on the underlying cause, treatment may involve surgery to remove the enlarged thyroid, hormone replacement, radiation, medications or no treatment at all. It's important for patients to see their physician regularly so the doctor can monitor their thyroid. Maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking, eating a well-balanced diet, getting regular exercise and wearing appropriate sun protection can help reduce the risk of developing a goitre.

Cardiomyopathy refers to any disease of the heart muscle. When the disease involves the ventricles, the lower chambers of the heart, the condition is known as dilated cardiomyopathy. Dilated cardiomyopathy occurs when the ventricles enlarge and weaken, reducing their ability to pump blood. This results in reduced blood flow to the body, causing fatigue, shortness of breath, irregular heartbeat, swelling in the legs, feet, ankles, abdomen, liver, neck, face, hands, fingers, weight gain, nausea, vomiting, lightheadedness, confusion, fainting and irregular heartbeat.

The four main types of cardiomyopathy are dilated, hypertrophic, restrictive and arrhythmogenic right ventricular. Dilated cardiomyopathy occurs when the heart becomes enlarged and weak. In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the walls of the heart thicken. With restrictive cardiomyopathy, the heart cannot relax normally, so the heart does not fill with blood properly. Finally, arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy affects the right ventricle and leads to the development of an irregular heartbeat.

People with cardiomyopathy often experience chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, lightheadedness, irregular heartbeat, swelling in the legs, feet, ankles, abdomen, neck, head, weight gain, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, anxiety, sweating, weakness, dizziness, fainting, confusion, poor memory, lack of concentration, insomnia, irritability, depression, personality changes, hair loss, cold intolerance, fatigue, rapid weight gain, fatigue, fatigue, weakness, tiredness, irregular heartbeat, lightheadedness, shortness of breath, swelling, cough, wheezing, excessive thirst, frequent urination, bloating, gas, constipation, indigestion, acid reflux, muscle cramps, joint pain, numbness, t

A physician will perform a physical exam to evaluate the patient's vital signs, listen to the heart with a stethoscope and feel the chest for enlargement. In some cases, the physician may order an echocardiogram, electrocardiogram, stress test, magnetic resonance imaging, computed tomography, angiogram, biopsy, Holter monitoring, event recorder monitoring, transesophageal echocardiogram, right heart catheterization, left ventriculogram, radionuclide ventriculography, myocardial perfusion scintigraphy, coronary angiogram, electrophysiologic study, endomyocardial biopsy, endomyocardial biopsy, myocardial biopsy, right ventriculogram, transoesophageal echocardiogram, transthoracic echocardiogram,

Unfortunately, there is no cure for cardiomyopathy. The disease is chronic and progresses slowly over time. Some patients do well for many years while others experience worsening symptoms that eventually require treatment. It is important for patients to work closely with their physicians to manage the disease and reduce the risk of complications. Lifestyle modifications are critical, as patients need to make significant lifestyle changes to improve the function of the heart. In some patients, these modifications can significantly slow the progression of the disease. In patients with worsening symptoms, medications are used to help the heart work better. Medications used to treat cardiomyopathy can have significant side effects, so patients should work closely with their physicians to determine the most effective medication regimen. In patients whose symptoms are not controlled with medications, an implantable defibrillator may be recommended to reduce the risk of sudden death. In

In people with cardiomyopathy, it's important to eat a heart-healthy diet that's low in saturated fat, cholesterol, salt and sugar. Maintaining a healthy weight is important, as obesity puts added stress on the heart. Exercise is recommended, as long as the doctor gives the go ahead. It's best to start out slowly and work up to 30 minutes of physical activity at least five days a week. Talk to the doctor about medications that can help protect the heart, like beta blockers. It's important to quit smoking and limit alcohol intake.

Osteoarthritis causes stiffness, swelling, tenderness, pain and decreased range of motion in the joint. Pain is the primary symptom, and the joint is the most commonly affected. Joint stiffness, particularly after rest, is a common symptom. Osteoarthritis is a progressive joint disease that leads to stiffness, swelling, pain, tenderness, creaking, grating, locking, and reduced range of motion. Although osteoarthritis cannot be cured, there are many treatment options that can reduce the symptoms and improve quality of life. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are the mainstay of treatment. Injections of steroids into the joint are another treatment option that is frequently used to reduce swelling. Hyaluronic acid injections are a relatively new treatment that involves injecting hyaluronic acid, a substance found naturally in the body, into the joint. Surgery is the final treatment option and is typically recommended only for patients with advanced osteoarthritis who do not respond to nonsurgical treatments. Surgical procedures can involve shaving the b

Osteoarthritis causes stiffness, swelling, tenderness and pain in the joints. Pain is the primary symptom, and the joint may feel stiff and sore. Sometimes the joint feels weak, and the person may experience locking, giving way, catching, grinding, crackling, snapping, grating, popping, aching, burning, throbbing, stiffness, tenderness, swelling, deformity, redness, warmth, decreased range of motion, crepitation, crunching, grating, grating, snapping, popping, catching, giving way, locking, weakness, fatigue, weight gain, weight loss, fever, rash, bruising, numbness, tingling, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, anxiety, depression, trouble concentrating, irritability, insom

Risk factors for osteoarthritis include obesity, joint injury, family history, aging, gender and occupation. Being overweight puts extra stress on the knees, hips, ankles, fingers, wrists, elbows, shoulders, neck, back, hands, feet, hip, spine, sacroiliac and tailbone. Being active throughout one's lifetime helps to reduce the risk of osteoarthritis. It is important for individuals to maintain a healthy weight to protect the knees from excess pressure. It is important to wear proper footwear to reduce stress on the knees, ankles, hips, wrists, fingers, elbows, shoulders, neck, back, hands, feet, hip, spine, sacroiliac and tailbone. It is important for individuals to participate in low-impact exercises to reduce stress on the knees,

While there is currently no cure for osteoarthritis, there are a number of lifestyle modifications that can help reduce joint pain and stiffness. Exercising regularly can improve range of motion, increase strength, reduce stiffness, improve balance, increase endurance and enhance mental outlook. Weight loss can help take pressure off the knee joint, while losing extra pounds can reduce stress on weight-bearing joints. Maintaining a healthy body weight can help protect the knees from developing osteoarthritis. Applying heat to sore joints can reduce stiffness. Taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications can reduce swelling, stiffness, pain and fever. Using assistive devices, such as canes, crutches, splints, walkers, wheelchairs, ramps, grab bars, raised toilet seats, tub benches

Children with autism have impaired language skills, poor social interactions, repetitive behaviors, and unusual reactions to sights, smells, sounds, tastes, textures, light, color, movement, sound, taste, temperature, pain, and balance. Parents often notice delays in the first 18 months of a child's life, such as not smiling, pointing, or looking at others. Many children have unusual reactions to sights, smells, sounds, tastes, textures, light, color, movement, sound, taste, temperature, pain, and balance. Other signs and symptoms that parents and doctors look for are problems with eye contact, gesturing, and joint attention. Some children have unusual reactions to the way things feel, look, smell, and taste. For example, some children refuse to wear clothes that itch, scratch, or tag, while other children enjoy wearing the tags

Diagnosing ASD involves a comprehensive evaluation that looks at a child's medical history, development, behavior, communication, cognition, sensory processing, adaptive skills, family and environmental factors. It's important for parents to seek a thorough evaluation from a team of medical professionals with experience in diagnosing ASD. In some cases, children with ASD are misdiagnosed with ADHD, a learning disability, mental retardation, depression, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, Tourette syndrome, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, seizure disorder, hearing impairment, vision impairment, language delay, motor delay, tics, head injury, metabolic disorder, allergies, celiac disease, thyroid dysfunction, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, mitochondrial disorder, kidney

The current standard of care for autism is behavioral interventions. Medications are sometimes prescribed to control irritability, aggression, self-injurious behaviors, repetitive movements, seizures, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, anxiety, depression, sleep disturbances, gastrointestinal symptoms, urinary incontinence, constipation, headaches, migraines, restless leg syndrome, hyperhidrosis, hypotonia, hypertension, weight problems, dental problems, osteopenia, osteoporosis, thyroid dysfunction, neuroendocrine dysfunction, vitamin D deficiency, nutritional deficiencies, fatigue, chronic pain, immunodeficiency, allergy, respiratory symptoms, hypoglycemia, hyp

Yes, autism can occur at any age. Many children are diagnosed with autism between 24 and 30 months of age. In the U.S., approximately 1 in 68 children has some form of ASD. While the prevalence is higher among boys, about 1 in 42 has ASD. It's important to remember that everyone experiences ASD a little differently, so what works for one child with ASD may not work for another. Parents are encouraged to work closely with their child's medical team to create an individualized treatment plan.

Risk factors for autism include a family history of the disorder, older paternal age at the time of the child's birth, a younger maternal age, a premature birth, a low birth weight, a male child, and exposure to valproic acid while in the womb. It is important to remember, though, that no single risk factor is known to cause autism. In addition, the symptoms and characteristics of the disorder can vary significantly among children.

Parents should work with their child's therapists to come up with strategies to help improve their child's social skills. Sometimes children with ASD benefit from attending a summer camp that offers activities specifically designed for children with ASD. It's important for parents to teach their children the "unwritten" rules of social interactions, like using eye contact when speaking, holding hands while walking, or allowing another child to take the first turn at playing. Children with ASD benefit from learning the skills involved in having a conversation, such as sharing information, asking questions, taking turns and listening. Parents should practice these skills at home so that the child feels more comfortable using them in a group setting.

Acne occurs when sebum, dead skin cells, dirt, bacteria, or cosmetics clog pores. Hormones are another possible cause. Hormone fluctuations, such as during puberty, pregnancy, menopause, or oral contraceptive use, can increase oil production, causing clogged pores. Some medications, such as corticosteroids, lithium, testosterone, or iodides, can also cause acne. Certain cosmetics, hair products, or cleansers can clog pores, leading to acne. Stress, poor nutrition, or not washing your face regularly can also contribute to acne.

The best treatment for acne depends on the severity and location of the lesions, but the main goals are to reduce inflammation, kill bacteria, remove dead skin cells, unclog pores, reduce oil production, prevent scarring, and protect the skin from environmental irritants. Topical creams are the mainstay of acne therapy, and benzoyl peroxide is the main active ingredient. Oral antibiotics are effective, especially against cystic acne, and retinoids are very helpful against blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, nodules, cysts, and postinflammatory hyperpigmentation. Isotretinoin is the gold standard against cystic acne, but it is very expensive and carries significant risks, so it is usually reserved for patients with severe cystic acne that does not respond to other

Acne is classified into four main groups, and it is important for patients to understand which group they have because the treatment will vary. Inflammatory acne is the most severe and is marked by red, tender nodules that can become cystic. Nodulocystic acne is a severe form of inflammatory acne and is marked by large cysts that can cause scarring. Comedonal acne is the mildest form and is marked by whiteheads, blackheads, papules, pustules, nodules, cysts, pimples, redness, scaling, oily skin, and possible scarring. Hormonal acne occurs during adolescence and pregnancy and is marked by noninflammatory lesions.

Certain foods have been linked to acne, with dairy being the most well-studied. Several small studies have suggested a possible association between dairy consumption and acne, with the possible mechanism being the hormones found in milk. It is important to remember, though, that no strong conclusions can be drawn from the available research, and these results need to be confirmed in larger, better-designed studies. It is important to keep in mind, too, that some acne medications contain vitamin A derivatives, so patients taking acne medications should not consume large amounts of vitamin A.

Poor hygiene has not been shown to contribute to acne, although poor hygiene can increase the chances of infection. Some acne medications can irritate the skin, causing dryness, peeling, redness, itching, burning, scaling, cracking, stinging, swelling, tenderness, rash, discoloration, pain, crusting, oozing, weeping, scarring, burning, itching, scaling, peeling, flaking, roughness, cracking, thinning, thickening, hardening, reddening, swelling, itching, burning, scaling, peeling, flaking, roughness, cracking, thinning, thickening, hardening, reddening, swelling, itching, burning, scaling, peeling, flaking, roughness, cracking, thinning, thickening, hardening, reddening

While acne is not a life-threatening condition, it can have significant psychological effects and lead to scarring. Acne that goes untreated for an extended period can lead to the development of nodules, cysts, keloid scars, discoloration, pits, pockmarks, hypertrophic scarring, atrophy, pigment changes, or stretch marks. If acne is severe, it can lead to poor self-esteem, depression, anxiety, poor body image, low self-confidence, embarrassment, anger, shame, guilt, fear, sadness, anxiety, stress, isolation, withdrawal, poor school performance, problems at work, loss of relationships, loss of employment and loss of income.

Sickle cell disease is diagnosed through a complete medical history, physical exam and a complete blood count. In some cases, the doctor may order a bone marrow biopsy to help make a diagnosis. A bone marrow biopsy involves removing a small amount of bone marrow tissue and looking at it under a microscope. Sickle cell disease is inherited, so the doctor will want to know the medical history of the patient and the patient's family to see if anyone has had sickle cell disease. Common symptoms of ovarian cancer include pelvic or abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, constipation, gas, fatigue, back pain, frequent urination, vaginal discharge, irregular menstrual periods, weight gain, indigestion, heartburn, trouble eating, shortness of breath, swollen legs, itchy skin, headaches, dizziness, anxiety, depression, insomnia, memory problems, dry mouth, hoarseness, sores in the mouth, change in bowel movements, dark stool, rectal bleeding, difficulty swallowing, change in taste, bad breath, change in smell, change in skin, hair, nails, breast lumps, pain during intercourse, pain during urination, pain during bowel movements, pain during sexual intercourse, pain during pregnancy, irregular menstrual cycles, excessive bleeding, heavy bleeding

Ovarian cancer is diagnosed through a pelvic exam, transvaginal ultrasound, CA-125 blood test, CT scan, MRI and biopsy. It is important for patients to see their physician regularly to perform pelvic exams to look for ovarian cysts. A transvaginal ultrasound can help doctors evaluate cysts found during a pelvic exam. A CA-125 blood test measures the level of a protein produced by ovarian cancer cells. If the CA-125 is elevated, this suggests the patient has ovarian cancer. A CT scan uses X-rays to take detailed pictures of the organs, bones, soft tissues, blood vessels, lymph nodes, nerves, air in the chest, stomach, intestines, liver, spleen, pancreas, bladder, kidneys,

The standard treatment for ovarian cancer involves surgery to remove all visible cancer, chemotherapy to kill any cancer cells that were not removed, and sometimes radiation to kill any remaining cancer cells. Depending on the patient's overall health, her age, the stage of the cancer and her preference, she can receive chemotherapy before, during or after surgery. Sometimes radiation is given at the same time as surgery. Some patients are eligible to enroll in clinical trials that involve new chemotherapy drugs that have shown promising results in treating ovarian cancer.

Ovarian cancer occurs when abnormal cells grow out of control in one or both ovaries. These abnormal cells can form into cysts that grow to be about 2 inches across. Sometimes the cysts don't form, and the abnormal cells just grow and divide. Most ovarian cancers start in the epithelium, the thin tissue covering the ovary. When the epithelium grows abnormally, the cells can turn into cancer and form cysts. Cysts that form because of cancer are usually benign. If the cyst is not benign, the abnormal cells can continue to grow, forming a mass that is malignant. Malignant tumors that start in the epithelium are known as epithelial ovarian cancers. The cysts formed from epithelial ovarian cancers can be solid, liquid, or semisolid. The

While no one knows the exact cause of ovarian cancer, there are a number of risk factors that increase a woman's chances of developing the disease. A family history of ovarian, breast, colorectal, endometrial, pancreatic, stomach, esophageal, thyroid, melanoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, multiple myeloma, sarcoma, prostate, bladder, kidney, head, neck, brain, blood, bone, connective tissue, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, lung, thyroid, ovary, testis, cervix, colon, rectum, skin, soft tissue, blood vessel, brain, central nervous system, eye, ear, nose, mouth, pharynx, salivary gland, breast, thyroid, skin, blood, blood vessel, lung, brain,

While ovarian cancer is difficult to diagnose at an early stage, there are a number of risk factors that increase a woman's chances of developing the disease. Some of the risk factors for ovarian cancer include obesity, infertility, hormone replacement therapy, family history, endometriosis, pelvic radiation, smoking, alcohol use, breast cancer, and being of Ashkenazi Jewish heritage. It's important for women to see their physician regularly to discuss preventive measures.

Influenza, also called the flu, is a highly contagious respiratory infection. Most cases of the flu are mild and last a few days, but the illness can be severe in some patients and lead to hospitalization. There is no specific test to diagnose the flu, so physicians make the diagnosis by ruling out other viral infections that have similar symptoms. People with the flu often experience high fevers, chills, fatigue, headache, dry cough, runny nose, sore throat, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, weakness, dizziness, confusion, irritability, restlessness, loss of appetite, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, wheezing, sinus pressure, ear pressure, sinus congestion, sinus drainage, nasal discharge,

Influenza is a respiratory infection caused by the influenza virus. This virus is highly contagious and is spread when an infected individual coughs, sneezes, talks, shakes hands, uses a door knob, touches an object, or breathes. An individual is at highest risk of contracting the flu if he or she comes in direct contact with an infected individual. Those at the highest risk for contracting the flu include young children, the elderly, pregnant women, those with chronic medical conditions, and individuals with weakened immune systems.

Most patients with the flu recover at home within one week. Over-the-counter medications can help reduce fever, headache, sore throat, runny nose, cough, fatigue and body aches. It's important for patients to drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration. Those with high-risk conditions, such as pregnant women, patients with chronic medical problems, the very young and the elderly, should see their primary health care provider right away to determine the best treatment. Antiviral medications are recommended for patients at high risk of developing complications from the flu. They should start taking the medicine within 48 hours of onset of flu symptoms. Antivirals work best if given within 24-48 hours of onset of flu symptoms. They do not cure the flu, but they can shorten the duration and lessen the severity of the illness

Influenza vaccines come in the form of shots, inhaled sprays, live attenuated nasal spray and high dose shots. These vaccines protect against four main flu viruses, two A viruses and two B viruses. There are some new vaccines being studied that protect against up to eight viruses. It's important to get vaccinated each year, as the strains of the flu can change from one season to the next. The high dose shots are approved for those 65 years and older. The live attenuated nasal spray is only approved for healthy individuals between the ages of 2 and 49. It's important to talk to your physician about which vaccine is right for you.

All individuals are at risk for the flu, but the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that the elderly are the most at risk. Other high-risk groups include pregnant women, young children, those with chronic medical conditions, such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, cancer, neurologic conditions, liver disorders, kidney disorders, blood disorders, endocrine disorders, metabolic disorders, autoimmune disorders, HIV, AIDS, diabetes, obesity, neurodevelopment disorders, neurocognitive disorders, neurobehavioral disorders, neuromuscular disorders, musculoskeletal disorders, ocular disorders, ear, nose, throat, head, face, jaw, neck, eye, eardrum, mastoid process, sinuses, thyroid

Influenza can be spread when an infected individual coughs, sneezes, talks, shakes hands, uses a door knob, touches an object, then touches his or her nose, mouth, eyes, ears, etc. An individual is at highest risk for contracting the flu if he or she lives with an infected individual, works in a hospital, nursing home, daycare center, school, restaurant, airport, cruise ship, military base, or anywhere that many individuals come in close contact. It is important for everyone to wash his or her hands regularly, especially before eating, preparing food, using the restroom, changing a baby, blowing his or her nose, coughing, sneezing, wiping a runny nose, handling soiled tissues, using the telephone, shaking hands, petting an animal, using a stethoscope, using a
